displayed_text: Family Member: So if his bone scan shows progression, are you gonna be in touch with him then? Doctor: I am. Family Member: Then he will start that? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And either way I think I will give him a head’s up especially – do you know when – do you have an appointment to see him? Patient: No, no, not right now we don’t. Doctor: So if you want to come off then you should probably make an appointment with him. Okay because ah - regardless if the PSA is going up or if the scan is you know not even changing. If you want to come off study Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: then yeah it might be a good idea to make that so we sort of connect with him. Okay? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Does that sound good? Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Right, but I’m just… Doctor: Yeah, the standard… Family Member: Are there different types of… Doctor: Yes, there are different… Family Member: Okay. Doctor: …types of chemotherapy. The standard one for… Patient: For what I have. Doctor: …this one, for prostate cancer, is to start with Taxotere or Docetaxel and that would be what you would get. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: One of the things to consider is you know we do have a new hormonal therapy that is being tested and that would be one potential option for you to look into. Patient: Is that a study? Doctor: Yes.

Family Member: Every time you go there I mean you can’t get in to see him. I mean you’re there for hours. Doctor: I B___ City? Patient: B___ City, yeah. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So… Patient: So yeah I’d rather see somebody… Family Member: We burned that bridge. Patient: I’d rather see somebody… yeah can’t go back to that. Doctor: I know because honestly then maybe and that probably should get fixed – Family Member: Yes. Doctor: - even if we make decisions about chemotherapy or something we cannot afford to have a major source of infection sitting right there. So definitely that will hold up a lot of our decisions about other treatments for sure.

Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So those were there even before you started the Xofigo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The radiation. Patient: Right. Doctor: So right now I think we will be in just watch and wait mode because I see no recompelling reason to put you on a new treatment.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were not keen on getting cut open or getting your bowels or your pee’s re-routed. Patient: I’m really not. Doctor: I know you’re not. Patient: I mean, and they want me to put the bag on. Doctor: I know they do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You would actually get two bags. Patient: F*** you sayin’? Doctor: One pee, one poop. Patient: Oh, hell, no, doc! Doctor: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. My publicist is very on call. Doctor: Yeah. So anything new going on? Patient: No. I mean as far as how I feel. Doctor: How do you feel? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: No new pains? No new issues urinating? Nothing else? Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have any bone pain. Don’t have any muscle pain per se. Uh. Doctor: So today we’re just going to go over stuff. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it?

Patient: I’ve been lost that. I’ve been lost that. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But I lost more. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Look what I got up in here. All this is brand new. Everything is brand new. I got, uh, Doctor: At least you have an ID now, huh? Patient: Yeah, I got an ID. Patient: I doubt anybody gonna give me a Social Security card, though. Doctor: Let’s see on here. Um. So, you have Lupron and Patient: I was, I was lookin’ forward to takin’ that chemo, but I wasn’t worried about it. I just wanted to see whether, see this is what I wanted to do. I wanted to take it, G_ so I could see what type of effect would it take and then I would know and Doctor: No. Not if you just had started diarrhea, like just two, three days ago again. Patient: But I don’t know, I don’t know, I don’t know if it was the chemo ‘cuz I just had it, um Doctor: No. I don’t want the chemo to aggravate anything.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s a good idea. Just write them down though that way… Family Member: We’re not taking up a room? You want us to go back in the lobby? Doctor: If they need you to go to the lobby we’ll let you know. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Alright and did I – yeah you got your copy of – well this is your CAT scan and a copy too. Patient: Merci Beaucoup. Doctor: Hope for the best right? Patient: I’m still recovering from the call and everybody keeps pushing their hand out. Why don’t you do the fist bump? Doctor: Yeah the first bump. Yeah I guess I should get with the times. Patient: I guess the fist bump is less contagious isn’t it? Doctor: Okay now maybe. Yeah you’re right. Although my son has told me that is -

Patient: so no out-of-pocket for us? Doctor: Of gosh no that that you cannot get outside of the clinical trial. Patient: Really. Doctor: So you can’t get it if you tried. (Laughs) Patient: It’s so new. Uh and uh do you think within a month or two months we’ll know if it’s working? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah so I’m hoping to get you started within the next two or three weeks. Family Member: Oh yeah I mean we want to start right away. Patient: So do we schedule the appointment today? Doctor: For coming downtown? Yeah somebody will call you once we have everything. Patient: And so we’re not scheduling it today. Doctor: Do you want to come later on this week? Tell me what day works well and how long you need to think about the consent and everything? Patient: Just coming to the midtown? Family Member: To do the tests honey.

Family Member 1: And she does yoga. Doctor: I’m very relaxed in here. Oh my gosh. (laughing) Family Member 1: She teaches yoga too Doctor. Doctor: Are you okay? Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. I’m just concerned about that PSA going up. Doctor: Yeah so we gotta start. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay.
